title: Quiz 5: Operations & Anaesthesia
topicName: Unit Three Part Two : Abnormal Labour and Puerperium
description: Assessment on anaesthetic methods, risks like Mendelson's syndrome, and operative deliveries.

questions.question: What is the primary cause of Mendelson's Syndrome during general anaesthesia?

options.text: Aspiration of acidic gastric contents into the lungs

questions.explanation: Mendelson's Syndrome is chemical pneumonitis caused by inhaling acid stomach contents during anaesthesia induction.
questions.hint: Think about what might come 'up' from the stomach.

questions.question: Match the type of Episiotomy to its description:

pairs.right: Starts at midline, directed laterally at 45 degrees
Starts at midline, directed posteriorly towards anus
Starts midline, curves laterally to avoid anus
Starts to the side of the introitus (rarely used)

questions.explanation: Mediolateral is most common to avoid anal sphincter damage. Median heals best but risks tearing into the anus.
questions.hint: Direction of the cut determines the name.

questions.question: Arrange the steps for a Vacuum Extraction (Ventouse) delivery:

items.text: Apply cup to foetal head (near posterior fontanelle)
Release vacuum and remove cup after head delivery

questions.hint: You must secure the cup before pulling.

questions.question: What are the necessary conditions for a Forceps Delivery? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Forceps require full dilation, engagement, empty bladder, and rupture of membranes. Mento-posterior is a contraindication.

questions.question: Which type of Caesarean Section incision is preferred in modern obstetrics?
questions.explanation: LSCS is preferred due to less bleeding, better healing, and lower risk of rupture in future pregnancies.
questions.hint: It involves the thinner part of the uterus.

questions.question: Identify the risk described: 'Accidental puncture of the dura mater causing severe headache'.

richContent.content: Complication: Occurs during epidural insertion when the needle advances too far.

questions.explanation: A Dural Tap leaks CSF, causing a spinal headache.

questions.question: Episiotomy repair should be delayed for 24 hours to allow swelling to subside.
questions.explanation: Episiotomy must be repaired immediately after the third stage to prevent infection and promote healing before edema sets in.
questions.hint: Open wounds are a risk for infection and bleeding.

questions.question: What are potential complications for the baby following Forceps Delivery? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Forceps apply pressure to the head, risking nerve damage, bleeding, and bruising. Femur fractures are associated with breech delivery.
questions.hint: Injuries related to the head and face.

questions.question: A ___BLANK___ Caesarean Section incision is made vertically in the upper uterine segment and is rarely used today.
questions.explanation: The Classical C-section is associated with a higher risk of rupture.

questions.question: How is Aortocaval Occlusion (Supine Hypotension) prevented during labour or surgery?
questions.explanation: By tilting the mother to the left (using a wedge or pillow), the weight of the uterus is shifted off the inferior vena cava.
